en_second_half: threw it down the road. It slammed into the wet asphalt and skidded in a shower of sparks for about half a mile before coming to a stop. The gas tank exploded.
en_Completion: slammed it to the ground, the impact sending shockwaves through the air. The bull-man's roar echoed through the streets, causing windows to shatter and buildings to tremble. Gabe's eyes widened in horror as he watched his beloved Camaro crumple like a tin can, the sound of crunching metal and shattering glass filling the air.

en_first_half: I stared across the meadow. There were groves of trees, a winding stream, acres of strawberries spread out under the blue sky. The valley was surrounded by
en_second_half: rolling hills, and the tallest one, directly in front of us, was the one with the huge pine tree on top. Even that looked beautiful in the sunlight.
en_Completion: hills, which were covered in a thick layer of green grass, and dotted with wildflowers of every color. The air was filled with the sweet scent of blooming flowers and the gentle hum of bees as they flitted from blossom to blossom. A faint mist rose from the valley floor, casting a mystical spell over the entire scene. It was as if time itself had slowed down, and all that existed was this perfect, serene moment.

en_first_half: We must’ve been on the north shore of Long Island, because on this side of the house, the valley marched all the way up to the water, which glittered about a mile in the distance. Between here and there, I simply couldn’t process everything I was seeing. The landscape was dotted with buildings that looked like ancient Greek architecture-an open-air pavilion, an amphitheater, a circular arena-except that they all looked brand new,
en_second_half: their white marble columns sparkling in the sun. In a nearby sandpit, a dozen high school-age kids and satyrs played volleyball. Canoes glided across a small lake. Kids in bright orange T-shirts like Grover’s were chasing each other around a cluster of cabins nestled in the woods. Some shot targets at an archery range. Others rode horses down a wooded trail, and, unless I was hallucinating, some of their horses had wings.
en_Completion: as if they had been built yesterday. The pavilion was surrounded by a lush garden, with flowers and trees that seemed to be in full bloom, despite the fact that it was the middle of winter. The amphitheater was filled with people, all dressed in white robes, who seemed to be engaged in some sort of ritual or ceremony. The arena was empty, but I could see a group of people gathered around the entrance, as if they were waiting for something to begin

en_first_half: My fingers curled around the Minotaur’s horn. I thought about my mom, but I had good thoughts: her smile, the bedtime
en_second_half: stories she would read me when I was a kid, the way she would tell me not to let the bedbugs bite.
en_Completion: stories she used to tell me, the way she always knew how to make me feel better when I was down. I thought about my friends, and how much I loved them, and how much they loved me. I thought about the adventures we had shared, and the memories we had made together. I thought about the future, and all the possibilities that lay ahead. I thought about the Minotaur, and how it had become a symbol of hope and strength for me.
vi_first_half: Tay tôi nắm chặt chiếc sừng kỷ niệm. Trong một thoáng, mọi ký ức đẹp đẽ về mẹ ùa tới: nụ cười dịu dàng, cuốn truyện
vi_second_half: mẹ đọc cho tôi đi ngủ hồi tôi còn bé… Tôi nhớ cả cách mẹ dạy làm thế nào để khỏi bị rệp cắn khi đi ngủ.
vi_Completion: đêm, ánh mắt ấm áp, và những lời khuyên nhủ đầy tình yêu thương. Mẹ luôn là người thầy, người bạn, và người mẹ tuyệt vời nhất của tôi. Những ký ức đó khiến tôi cảm thấy ấm áp và hạnh phúc, như thể mẹ vẫn đang ở bên cạnh tôi.
es_first_half: Mis dedos se cerraron alrededor del cuerno del Minotauro. Pensé en mi madre, pero sólo tuve buenos pensamientos: su sonrisa, las historias que me
es_second_half: leía antes de irme a la cama cuando era pequeño, la manera en que me decía que no dejara que me picaran los mosquitos.

en_first_half: Despite all that, I liked camp. I got used to the morning fog over the beach, the smell of hot strawberry fields in the afternoon, even the weird noises of monsters in the woods at night. I would eat dinner with cabin eleven, scrape part of my meal into the fire, and try to feel some connection
en_second_half: to my real dad. Nothing came. Just that warm feeling I’d always had, like the memory of his smile. I tried not to think too much about my mom, but I kept wondering: if gods and monsters were real, if all this magical stuff was possible, surely there was some way to save her, to bring her back….
en_Completion: to the land, to the spirits that lived here. I would listen to the stories of the old ones, of the great battles and the powerful magic that once flowed through this place. I would feel the weight of history, the depth of the roots that connected this land to the people who had lived here for generations. And I would try to find my own place in it all, to understand where I fit into the larger story of this land and its people.

Chúng tôi thường chia sẻ những câu chuyện về gia đình, về những điều chúng tôi yêu thích, và về những ước mơ trong tương lai.

en_first_half: By some miracle, I was still alive. I didn’t want to look underneath the ruins of my shredded armor. My chest felt warm
en_second_half: and wet, and I knew I was badly cut. Another second, and the monster would’ve turned me into a hundred pounds of delicatessen meat.
en_Completion: and sticky, and I could feel a slow trickle of blood dripping down my side. I tried to move, but a wave of pain washed over me, making my vision blur. I gritted my teeth and forced myself to sit up, surveying the damage. My armor was in tatters, the metal plates dented and twisted beyond recognition. I gingerly lifted the edge of my breastplate, wincing as I saw the jagged gash in my side.

en_first_half: The attic was filled with Greek hero junk: armor stands covered in cobwebs; once-bright shields pitted with rust; old leather steamer trunks plastered with stickers saying ITHAKA, CIRCE’S ISLE, and LAND OF THE AMAZONS. One long table was stacked with glass jars filled with
en_second_half: pickled things-severed hairy claws, huge yellow eyes, various other parts of monsters. A dusty mounted trophy on the wall looked like a giant snake’s head, but with horns and a full set of shark’s teeth. The plaque read, HYDRA HEAD #1, WOODSTOCK, N.Y., 1969.
en_Completion: strange, glowing liquids; another was heaped with yellowed scrolls and tomes bound in cracked leather. In the corner, a beautiful wooden rocking chair sat shrouded in a faded tapestry, looking like it hadn't been sat in for centuries. The air was thick with dust and the scent of old books and forgotten memories. A faint hum of magic lingered, like the echo of a long-forgotten spell. Amidst the clutter, a single, flick

en_first_half: “The sword is celestial bronze. Forged by the Cyclopes, tempered in the heart of Mount Etna, cooled in the River Lethe. It’s deadly to monsters, to any creature from the Underworld, provided they don’t kill you first. But the blade
en_second_half: will pass through mortals like an illusion. They simply are not important enough for the blade to kill. And I should warn you: as a demigod, you can be killed by either celestial or normal weapons. You are twice as vulnerable.”
en_Completion: will shine with a faint blue glow whenever this happens. The blade will also glow whenever it detects the presence of a monster, making it a useful tool for detecting and tracking them. The sword is virtually indestructible and can withstand even the most powerful attacks. However, it is not invincible and can be damaged or broken if subjected to enough force. The sword's power is also tied to the user's life force, so if the user is injured or weakened, the sword

en_first_half: The moment I touched the shield, I knew we were in trouble. My hand broke through something that had been connecting it to the dashboard. A cobweb, I thought,
en_second_half: but then I looked at a strand of it on my palm and saw it was some kind of metal filament, so fine it was almost invisible. A trip wire.
en_Completion: but it was too thick, too sticky. I pulled my hand back, and a long, gooey strand of something came with it. I looked up at the dashboard, and that's when I saw it. A small, round, pulsing thing was attached to the shield. It was about the size of a golf ball, and it was covered in tiny, glowing symbols. I knew we were in trouble. I knew we had to get out of there, fast.</

en_first_half: But the thing wasn’t attacking. It was nuzzling me. Heeling like a dog. Tentatively, I touched its dorsal fin. It bucked a little, as if inviting me to hold tighter. I grabbed the fin with both hands. It took off, pulling me along. The shark carried me down
en_second_half: into the darkness. It deposited me at the edge of the ocean proper, where the sand bank dropped off into a huge chasm. It was like standing on the rim of the Grand Canyon at midnight, not being able to see much, but knowing the void was right there.
en_Completion: into the darkness, the water pressure building in my ears. I felt a rush of excitement mixed with fear as the shark dove deeper, the light from above growing dimmer. The shark's fin was smooth and cool to the touch, and I held on tight, my heart racing with anticipation. We descended into the unknown, the darkness enveloping us like a shroud.

en_second_half: ground at my feet, but I still couldn’t figure out where it was coming from.
en_Completion: ground beneath our feet. The gates were old and rusty, and they creaked and groaned as we pushed them open. We walked further in, our footsteps echoing off the walls. Suddenly, we heard a faint whispering in our ears.

en_first_half: It was as if a cloud covered the sun, but worse. Light faded. Sound and color drained away. A cold, heavy presence
en_second_half: passed over the beach, slowing time, dropping the temperature to freezing, and making me feel like life was hopeless, fighting was useless.
en_Completion: settled over the land, like a shroud cast over the world. The air grew thick and heavy, weighing down upon the shoulders of all who dwelled within its reach. The once vibrant hues of nature dulled, as if the very essence of life was being slowly extinguished. The sounds of laughter and joy, of birds singing and leaves rustling, were silenced, leaving only an oppressive stillness. It was as if the very fabric of existence was unraveling,
